entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Medieval Latin instant-, instans, from instant-, instans, adjective, instant, from Latin

def.dt: :a point in time separating two states at the instant of death

entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French or Latin; Anglo-French, from Latin instant-, instans, from present participle of instare to stand upon, urge, from in- + stare to stand stand

def.dt: :present current previous felonies not related to the instant crime
:of or occurring in the present month abbreviation inst
:immediate direct the play was an instant success
:premixed or precooked for easy final preparation instant pudding
:appearing in or as if in ready-to-use form instant poetry
:produced or occurring with or as if with extreme rapidity and ease
:a means or system for transmitting electronic messages instantly
:a video recording of an action (as a play in football) that can be played back (as in slow motion) immediately after the action has been completed
